subject: Add a new interface "OriginatedBy"
commitMessage:
Add a new interface "OriginatedBy"

This interface can be implemented by the dbus objects
of any application/service that has a requirement to store
the identity of the "originator" that has caused the activity.
This unique id is stored in the "OriginatorId" property and
"OriginatorType" helps identify the type of originator.

Signed-off-by: Asmitha Karunanithi <asmitk01@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Ia96592bbe4a7b0057fe66f8e1f09d73837978c30

I think "InitiatedBy" would be more suitable.
Sure, Though I have a few suggestions like OriginatedBy, StartedBy, I think IntitatedBy fits in better.
Please remove this statement. BMC does not ensure that the client who originated the dump only can download this. BMC just tags the session id to the dump entry for the user initiated dumps.

InitiatedBy ? 
This data does not "Manage" the dump entry. Maintainers can share their views here please.

Sure, Though I have a few suggestions like OriginatedBy, StartedBy, I think IntitatedBy fits in better.

Maintainers, your thoughts here please.
Remove this statement. There is no restriction at BMC
can this a separate interface instead of putting in dump entry?

How will this map to like Redfish?
Id doesn't sound very interoperable.
"Id of the external user" doesn't really explain what it is.

Done.
Changed it to GeneratorId which will store any unique id of the user
IBM is currently implementing this as OEM, and DMTF is discussing to get this added to LogEntry schema
Why do we need this on Dump and as a separate interface.?

So I have kept this as a separate interface because, any dbus object can implement this interface to indicate who has initiated the activity/operation, if applicable.
This is because, the DMTF community also seem to need this interface for audit logs (forum thread at: https://redfishforum.com/thread/547/usage-originofcondition-parameter-logentry-schema)

This "GeneratorId" is needed here in the Create dump method as an additional parameter, whose value if not null, will then be populated in the dump entry dbus object.
So all the user initiated dumps will have this assitional parameter with the unique id as its value.
This enum should be moved to xyz as this one is being used in BMC dump
I still have concerns about this being interoperable. A free-form string means users can put whatever they want in it. How does this map to Redfish?

IMU, this should be taken care in the implementation.
Example: for dumps, client ip that has caused the dump creation will be assigned to this property and the bmcweb will then display it in the redfish response.

Likewise, whereever this prop is implemented, they must be assigning any unique id of the entity that has caused the operation and then should send it in the redfish response.

I don't see how this corresponds to the design document directly.

Is there wide use for a new "GeneratedBy" interface?  What are the valid values of the strings here?

For now, we are planning to use it for the dumps, to keep track of who initiated the dump.
In future, if there is a need in any app, for saving the initiator's id, probably they can implement this interface in their dbus object.

There is no solid definition of this property's value until Redfish standardizes this. Right now, it is just a string - client's ip address (for dumps).
https://redfishforum.com/thread/547/usage-originofcondition-parameter-logentry-schema

> There is no solid definition of this property's value until Redfish standardizes this. Right now, it is just a string - client's ip address (for dumps).

ip address??  I would have never figured that out from anything you've written so far.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/47060
This commit contains the implementation..
It is still in "WIP" state because i have to update the changes w.r.t this interface.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/+/48337 this is the debug collector change.

@Patrick,
https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/LogEntry.v1_11_0.json describes the "GeneratorId" property. Its a string type. There is no hard rule that it has to be the IP address. Its up to the implementation to populate a unique id of the device that has generated the specific object

This is the Redfish information:

  "GeneratorId": {
    "description": "An identifier of the device that has generated the IPMI SEL Event Record.",

This might be something like "CPU-0".  And for that I would agree that it is a "generator".  What you have described above is an Initiator.  Are you overloading a Redfish field for something other than what it is intended?

"Unique Id of the user" doesn't sound like an IP address either.

If you want this to be in common it needs to be better defined.

I checked the redfish schema in detail. The GeneratorId is not the right property. That is for the IPMI SEL events only. Apologies for the confusion.

We should be considering the property - "Originator". This is a enum named "OriginatorType" - which is either "Client", "Internal" or "SupportingService". These can have string values.

We can rename it as Originator/Initiator. Patrick can you please suggest which name is most suitable?

We have the below from redfish (from the latest schema release)

https://redfish.dmtf.org/schemas/v1/LogEntry.v1_11_0.json
                "Originator": {
                    "description": "The source of the log entry.",
                    "longDescription": "This property shall contain the source of the log entry.",
                    "readonly": true,
                    "type": "string",
                    "versionAdded": "v1_11_0"
                },
                "OriginatorType": {
                    "$ref": "#/definitions/OriginatorTypes",
                    "description": "The type of originator data.",
                    "longDescription": "This property shall contain the type of originator data.",
                    "readonly": true,
                    "versionAdded": "v1_11_0"
                },
                
So; i think we can name this interface/property as "OriginatorId"

The Redfish ones are an enumeration though: { Client , Internal , SupportingService }.  Is this sufficient for our needs?  I think we should be documenting what the expectations are for this string in order to make life easier on the Redfish implementation.  Ideally they are enums and/or domain-enums (like the parameters to CreateDump).

I think yes. This makes sense

I have added OriginatorType as one of the properties that is an enumeration type which helps identify the originator tyoe.
I don't think "Generator" is the correct verb here.  The user isn't generating the dump; they are maybe initiating it?

Do you think, InitiatorId would fit here?

If so, then probably the interface name also should be renamed from GeneratedBy to InitiatedBy
DMTF named it as "GeneratedBy". Going with the same name at Dbus as well
are we defining these unique ids somewhere?

In the design doc it is included
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/47446

Do i need to define it elsewhere?
This is not needed correct ? This enum is not needed while creating dump. AdditionalData property can contain the input parameters for createDump as key:value pairs.

This can be used not only for the user triggered actions, but also can be used for the internally triggered activities by any software or hardware resource.
So i think you can remove the 'user' here and mention 'orginator'

Now I'm lost.  

We added OriginatorType, which corresponds to a Redfish property, but we didn't remove OriginatorId or define a schema for it.  Who is the user of OriginatorId if it isn't Redfish and what do appropriate values look like.  "Unique Id of the originator" doesn't tell me enough to know, as a developer, what kind of values I should be filling in here.  And, we generally do not allow arbitrary strings to be filled into dbus objects because there is no programatic way to interpret them so we end up with random keys spread across the codebase.

The definition of what this "OriginatorId" string should be is application/service specific.

The service that uses this interface, must decide on what can be stored in this string. Example, for dumps (user-generated dumps), the originator's IP address will be stored in this property.

> The definition of what this "OriginatorId" string should be is application/service specific.

Who/what is the user of this data then?  If they are intended to be used only as part of the dump data itself (used back in IBM maybe?), that is fine, but we do not allow programmatic interpretation of arbitrary strings.

You will see a number of place in the YAML file where we make a similar statement.  I'd like to see it added here as a comment as well, if this is your intention.

```
yaml/org/open_power/Logging/PEL/Entry.interface.yaml:          not be used for programmatic interrogation of an object.
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Decorator/LocationCode.interface.yaml:          programmatic interrogation of an inventory object.
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Decorator/ManufacturerExt.interface.yaml:          These fields must not be used for programmatic interrogation of
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Decorator/ManufacturerExt.interface.yaml:          programmatic interrogation should be promoted to a first-class
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Decorator/UniqueIdentifier.interface.yaml:          programmatic interrogation of an object.
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Inventory/Item/Cable.interface.yaml:          in user interfaces but this field should not be used for programmatic
```

If somehow programmatic usage of this value *within* the BMC is your intention, then arbitrary strings are not acceptable.

> You will see a number of place in the YAML file where we make a similar statement.  I'd like to see it added here as a comment as well, if this is your intention.

+1

This interface is used at IBM systems for a user triggered dump usecases. This is added as an independent interface, so that it can be used in any other applications, who need to save/audit; as who created/initiated the action in the system.
